summary: This is an internal FBI email chain from August 20, 2019, discussing the handling and status of hard drives seized in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The emails reveal that drives were initially missed during a search, later recovered from a third party's residence, and are undergoing forensic processing with concerns about encryption and privileged information. The Deputy Director (DD) and other senior FBI officials are prioritizing the examination for potential leads on co-conspirators.

persons.name: ADIC
persons.context: Mentioned as having informed the Deputy Director about evidence received from a third party's residence in the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: CID
persons.context: Listed among officials inquiring about the prioritization of exploiting media evidence that may lead to co-conspirators.

persons.name: EAD
persons.context: Requested clarification on evidence sheets and asked the Operational Technology Division to be on standby for questions.

events.title: Evidence received from third-party residence
events.description: Evidence (hard drives) related to the Epstein investigation was received from a third party's residence. The residence owner turned it over quickly, stating an associate had placed it there.

events.title: Media evidence received by FBI
events.description: Evidence sheets indicate media was received on this date, but details about encryption or association with the third-party residence were unclear.

events.title: FBI leadership prioritizes evidence exploitation
events.description: The Deputy Director (DD), ADIC, and CID inquire about prioritizing the forensic exploitation of recovered media drives, as they may lead to identification of co-conspirators, attracting the Attorney General's attention.

keyFacts: Hard drives central to the Epstein investigation were initially in a safe during a first search warrant but could not be seized due to lack of authority; they were missing when investigators returned a week later.

The drives were later recovered after the individual who took them was contacted and brought them over 'right away.' They are being processed through a 'taint process' due to potential privileged information.
There is internal confusion about whether the drives are encrypted, with one official indicating they appeared encrypted, while another states they are 'not encrypted to my knowledge.'

Senior FBI leadership, including the Deputy Director, is directly involved and prioritizing the forensic examination of this media because it 'may lead to co-conspirators,' which has the attention of the Attorney General.
The evidence was placed at a third party's residence by an associate of Epstein; the residence owner turned it over quickly, stating he 'didn't want to have anything to do with it.'
